Manx: T’eh gobbraghey nish whooinney ...kys t’ou ansherbee?
English: It’s working now yessir...how are you anyway?

Manx: Cha nel mee ro-olk
English: I’m not too bad

Manx: S’mie shen
English: That’s good

Manx: Va mee lane çhing bunnys daa vee er dy henney. (row?) Va mish as my ven nyn lhie rish bunnys shiaghtin; agh ta shin couyral nish. (s’mie shen)Bwooise da Jee. (beggan ny share nish ansherbee) Va doghan goll mygeayrt er y twoaie
English: I was terribly ill nearly two months ago (Were you?) I and my wife were in bed for nearly a week; but we have recovered now. (That’s good). Thanks to God. (a little better anyway) There was a bug going around the north.

Manx: Vel?
English: Is there?

Manx: Nagh row yn red shen er y jiass?
English: Wasn’t the same thing in the south?

Manx: Cha nel ayns sy jiass whooinney.... ta reddyn slane yindyssagh ayns y jiass; ta reddyn beggan anchasley ayns y twoaie ta mee clashtyn
English: Not in the south yessir...things are really wonderful in the south; things area a little different in the north I hear.

Manx: Ram reddyn anchaslys rish y twoaie. Cha nel ad gollrish ayns shoh whooinney... ta shiuish sleih elley er y jiass
English: Loads of different things in the north. They are not like you lot here yessir...you are other people in the south.

Manx: Ta fys aym
English: I know

Manx: As Kuse dy vleeantyn er dy henney va ram caggey ayn eddyr ain hene – eddyr y jiass as y twoaie
English: And several years ago there was a lot of wars between us...between the south and the north

Manx: Bwooise da Jee nagh vel yn lheid goll er y laa t’ayn nish
English: Thanks be to God that the like isn’t happening today now

Manx: Cha nel eh ro olk nish
English: It’s not too bad now.

Manx: Ta mee clashtyn dy vel slieh giu ushtey quaagh sy twoaie
English: I hear that people drink strange water in the north

Manx: Quaagh agglagh as mish nyn mast’eu
English: Very strange water and me amongst them

Manx: Vel?
English: Yes?

Manx: My ta shiu shirrey er coloayrtys cha bee agh boghtynid ry gheddyn voym’s
English: If you are after me for some conversation it will only be rubbish that you get from me

Manx: Ta fys aym. My ta mee shirrey red ennagh jeh scansh ta mee loayrt rish sleih sy jiass agh my ta mee shirrey boghtynid ta mee çheet dys yn twoaie
English: I know. If I am after something of importance I speak to people in the south but if it’s rubbish I’m after I come to the north

Manx: Er y twoaie...shen eh
English: On the north...that’s it

Manx: Vel shen yn red ry-yannoo?
English: Is that the thing to do?

Manx: Cha nel yn ‘irrinys ry-gheddyn er y twoaie
English: Truth isn’t to be had in the north

Manx: Nagh vel?
English: Isn’t there?

Manx: Cha nel eh gollrish Radio Vannin
English: It’s not like Manx Radio

Manx: Cha nel
English: No

Manx: Ta’n irrinys ayns shen
English: The truth is there

Manx: Ooilley sleih ass nyn ging ayns yn twoaie
English: All people out of their minds in the north

Manx: Oh dy jarroo...as my t’ad gra hig emshyr feer vie ayns radio Vannin, well hig ee
English: Oh indeed...and if they say on Manx Radio that there will be good weather in then it will come

Manx: S’mie shen
English: That’s good

Manx: She laa braew grianagh t’ayn jiu ayns yn twoaie agh ayns y jiass t’eh ceau fliaghey. (shen eh) Vel eh dy kinjagh myr shoh ayns y twoaie?
English: It’s a fine day in the north today but in the south it’s raining. (that’s it)

Manx: dy kinjagh whooinney... cha nel red erbee olk er y twoaie. (shen yindyssagh) cho leah as ta shiu cosney çheu-sthie jeh yn awin ta shiu ayns çheer er-lheh, dy bollagh
English: O indeed yessir...things are not bad in the north. (that’s wonderful) As soon as you get outside the river you are in a completely different/ special country

Manx: Smooinnee mee dy row
English: I thought as much

Manx: Ta’n sleih...sleih er-lheh chammah as dy chooilley nhee elley. T’ad.
English: The people...special people as well as everything else. They are.

Manx: Ta blass quaagh er y twoaie
English: There is a strange accent in the North.

Manx: Vel?
English: Is there?

Manx: Ta ta
English: Yes, yes

Manx: Blass quaagh ayns Gaelg
English: Strange accent in Manx.

Manx: Ayns Gaelg... Ta shin gra ‘kione’ cha nel shin gra ‘kiodn’ ny reddyn myr shen
English: In Manx...we say ‘Head’ we don’t say ‘head’ or things like that

Manx: As ‘braew’ cha nel... ta shin...gra ‘braew’
English: And ‘braew’ we don’t...we say...saying ‘braew’

Manx: Ta dagh ooilley nhee myr shen
English: Everything is like that

Manx: Oie vie... C’red t’ou gra son ‘oie vie’?
English: Good night...what do you say for ‘good night’

Manx: ‘Oie vie er y twoaie’ As ta shin gra ‘fuygh’ son ‘fuygh’ (vel?) as reddyn myr shen
English: ‘Oie vie’ in the north And we say ‘wood’ son ‘wood’ (Do you?) and things like that

Manx: As va Leslie jannoo spotçhyn. Haink eshyn ass y jiass, ass Purt ny h-Inshey dy ve firrinagh
English: And Leslie was doing jokes. He came from the south, out of Peel to be true

Manx: V’eh loayrt rish ‘ooh’ son ‘ooh’
English: He was saying ‘egg’ for ‘egg’

Manx: Va shin gee ‘oohyn’ son nyn anjeeal as va Leslie gee ‘oohyn’
English: We were saying ‘eggs’ for our breakfast and Leslie was saying ‘eggs’

Manx: Ec y jerrey v’eh cliaghtit rish ny fir ayns shoh as v’eh gra ‘Shegin dou geddyn ‘ooh’ son my anjeeal’
English: At the end he was used to those here and he was saying ‘I have to get ‘eggs’ for my breakfast’

Manx: Haink eh dy bee lane twoaieagh
English: He came to be a real northerner

Manx: Vel blass sy twoaie...vel shen bit beg ny share na blass ry gheddyn ayns sy jiass?
English: Is the accent of the north...is it a little better than the accent to be got in the jiass?

Manx: Well paart dy lheih gra myr shen as paart jeusyn ass y jiass, t’ad gra ny smessey er y twoaie
English: Well some people say that it is and some of them from the south, they say that it’s worse on the north

Manx: Vel ?
English: Do they?

Manx: Agh er my hon hene ta blass twoaie ny share foddey na blass er y jiass
English: But for myself the accent of the north is far better than that from the south

Manx: Foddee dy vel oo kiart
English: Perhaps, you’re right

Manx: Cre voish hooar oo yn Ghaelg ansherbee?...quoi voish hooar oo yn Ghaelg? ...(c’raad v’ou gynsaghey?)
English: Where did you get the Manx from anyway? From who did you get the Manx? (Where were you learning...?)

Manx: Ny fir share, foddee slieh gollrish yn Gaaue (yn Ghaaue, s’mie shen). Va mee cur shilley er y ghaaue nish as reesht marish Illiam pat y Radlagh
English: The best ones, perhaps people like Yn Gaaue (Yn Gaaue, that’s good). I was visiting the Gaaue now and again with Bill Radcliffe.

Manx: Va mee er y keayn rish bleeantyn as tra haink mee erash lurg yn chaggey va brastylyn goll er
English: I was on sea for years and when I came back after the war there were classes going on in

Manx: Rhumsaa as kuse dy sleih ayn; sleih gollrish Illiam Pat y Radlagh, Charles Mooar y Craine ass y Vank
English: Ramsey and a few people there; people like Bill Radcliffe, Big Charles Craine from the bank

Manx: Juan MacVarkish, Walter y Cleree as ram stoo myr shen. As nish as reesht va mee çheet erash dys Mannin er my laghyn seyrey
English: John Corkish, Walter Clarke and lots of stuff like that. And now and again I was coming back to Mannin on my holidays

Manx: as va mee goll stiagh ayns ny brastyl dy ‘eaishtagh rish ooilley yn chooish as va mee jannoo ram obbyr my lomarcan,
English: I was going to classes to listen to all the talk and I was doing loads of work myself,

Manx: as eer tra va me my phaitchyn goll mygeayrt er y twoaie va beggan dy Ghaelg goll er loayrt ...chooid smoo jeu jus ennym jeh reddyn va goll er loayrt
English: and even when I was a child going around on the north there was a little Manx being spoken...the most part of it just names of things that were spoken

Manx: dy cadjin, gollrish bangan, shibbyraghyn as reddyn myr shen, ushtey, voish yn shenn sleih
English: normally, like bough, suppers and things like that, water, from the old people.

Manx: Agh ghow mee tastey jeu...as va paart dy lioaryn Gaelgagh ayns yn thie ayms, shenn Vibleyn as y lhied
English: But I took notice of them...and there were some Manx books in my house, old Bibles and the like

Manx: as haink eh dy ve sym mooar orrym orroo, as ren mee my chooid share dy ynsaghey y grammar as dy lhaih assdaue
English: and I became really interested in them, and I did my best to learn the grammar and to read out of them

Manx: ...shen yn oyr dy row mee gynsaghey as va ram enmyn buill ayn ass y Ghaelg as va sym mooar ayms orroosyn
English: ...that’s the reason that I was learning, and there were loads of place names in Manx and I had great interest in them

Manx: as haink dagh ooilley nhee dy ve sneeuit cooidjagh whooinney as...ny s’ beggan as ny s’ beggan
English: and everything came to be spun together yessir and... little by little

Manx: haink ee rhym as ta beggan ayms nish... ga nagh vel caa ayms dy loayrt rish monney dy leih as Gaelg oc
English: I got it and there is a little at me yet...even if I don’t have the opportunity to speak to many people who have Manx

Manx: agh cha nel ny fir aeg as sym oc nish myr v’ad roie.
English: but the young ones don’t have as much interest in it as they once did.

Manx: Agh s’ quaagh eh dy vel ram Sostnee ec y çheer nish as ta sym ocsyn er y Ghaelg ga nagh vel caa oc d’ynsaghey ee
English: But it’s strange that there are many English people in the country now and they have an interest in the Manx even if they don’t have an opportunity to learn it

Manx: Eer jus kuse dy shiaghteeyn er dy henney v’ad cur uinnag vooar ayns y cheeill ayns shoh (Keeill Yude) as va’n ard-jaghin ayn dy chummal y shirveish dy cur moylley jee
English: Even just a couple of weeks ago they were putting a large window in the church here (St Judes) and the archdeacon was holding the service of praise

Manx: as haink kuse dy Hostnee rhym as dooyrt ad ‘nagh by vie lhiat lhaih lessoon ass y Ghaelg ec y çhirveishagh?’
English: and some English people came to me and they said ‘ wouldn’t you like to read a lesson in Manx at the service?’

Manx: As dooyrt mee ‘by vie lhiam shen y yannoo’ as ren mee myr shen as va mee lhaih ass y Ghaelg as v’ad geiyrt orrym ayns y Vaarle ayns duillag er-lheh
English: And I said ‘I would like to do that’ and I did that and I was reading in Manx and they were following me in English on a special sheet

Manx: as lurg y çhirveish dooyrt ad dy row ad lane ghraihagh er y çhengey jus dy eaishtagh ree as haink ben er-lheh ayms
English: and after the service they said that they loved just to hear the language...some particular woman came to me

Manx: as dooyrt ee ‘va shen yn chied cheayrt dy row mee er ve geaishtagh rish yn çhengey shen as va mee coontey mooar jee’ dooyrt ee... cha nel shen ro olk
English: and she said, ‘that was the first time that I was hearing that language and I thought a lot of it’ she said...that’s not too bad.

Manx: As adsyn ooilley nyn Sostnee ....ta fys oc, tra t’ad geaishtagh rish y çhengey ta fys oc dy row ee ayn keayrt dy row as dy vel ee bentyn rish yn eiraght ain
English: And them all English...they know, when they are listening to the language, they know that it was there once and that it concerns our heritage

Manx: nagh vel ....?
English: doesn’t it...?

Manx: Lhisagh ad geaishtagh ree ny smoo na ta caa oc ec y traa t’ayn nish
English: They should listen to it more often than they have the opportunity to now

Manx: Shegin dooin loayrt assjee whooinney
English: We have to speak it yessir

Manx: (Shen scanshoil...l t’ou uss kiart whooinney)
English: (That’s important...you are right yessir)

Manx: Shegin dooin
English: We have to

Manx: Eer mannagh vel monney dy Ghaelgeyryn ayn as ta kuse jeu gynsaghey as t’ad çheet ny quail ayns
English: Even if there are not many Manx speakers around there are a few learning and they meet me in

Manx: Rhumsaa ayns Straid Skylley Chreest as t’ad gra ‘moghrey mie’ as reddyn myr shen as ‘kys ta shiu’ as ta moyrn dy loayrt ass y Ghaelg as ta cooney lieu ... lesh y çhengey
English: Ramsey in Parliament Street and they are saying ‘Good Morning’ and things like that and ‘How are you’ and there is pride speaking in Manx and helping them with the language

Manx: Nish as neesht ta paart dy Gaelgeyryn ayn as ram crack ain er y traid sleih gollrish... yn eeasteyr...cre ta’n ennym echey?
English: Now and again there are a few Manx speakers around and we have a lot of chat on the street...the fisherman...what’s his name?

Manx: David
English: David

Manx: Mac y eeasteyr... (ta ram Gaelg echey) t’eshyn er y twoaie nish as reesht as t’eh goll erash reesht dy tappee
English: The fisherman (he has a lot of Manx) he’s on the north now and again and he’s going back again quickly

Manx: Tra va sleih gollrish... Walter y Cleree ayn va mee dy mennick çheet ny quail dooinney as va ram Gaelg ain er y traid
English: When there were people like Walter Clarke around I was often meeting someone and we had loads of Manx on the street

Manx: Row uss marish Walter y Cleree goll dy chur shilley y Ghaaue ayns ny shenn laaghyn?
English: Were you with Walter going to visit the Gaaue in the old days?

Manx: Shen eh as yn chooid smoo jeu rish Illiam Pat y Radlagh.
English: That’s it and the most part of it with Walter Radcliffe

Manx: Ta cooinaghtyn ayms, un cheayrt va laa ruggyree yn Ghaaue ayn as haink Illiam as boteil ushtey, myr gooit dy chur da...
English: I remember once when it was the Gaaue’s birthday and William came with a bottle of water as a present to give to him...

Manx: as hug eh yn boteil shoh da’n Ghaaue as va’n Gaaue sheebey eh va cur y laue er as dooyrt eh ‘cre y sorch dy yough ta’n stoo shoh Illiam?
English: and he gave the bottle to the Gaaue and the Gaaue was blowing it, putting his hand on it and he said ‘What sort of drink is this stuff, William?’

Manx: As dooyrt Illiam ‘Cabbyl bane’
English: And William said, ‘White Horse’

Manx: As dooyrt yn Gaaue ‘shimmey keayrt ta mee er ve markiagh er y chabbyl shen’...nagh vel shen yindyssagh?
English: And the Gaaue said ‘Many times I have been riding on that horse’...isn’t that wonderful?

Manx: As v’eh dooinney doal ec yn traa shen as cha dod eh fakin veg agh v’eh jus cur y laue er y voteil as
English: And he was a blind man at that time and he couldn’t see anything but he was just putting his hand on the bottle and

Manx: va dooinney elley cur da paart dy hombaaghey ‘twist’ as reddyn myr shen jus dy lheeiney yn poib echey
English: there was another man giving him some tobacco ‘twist’ and things like that to fill his pipe.

Manx: Va laghyn mie ayns shen
English: Those were good days.

Manx: C’raad v’eh cummal ansherbee yn Gaaue?
English: Where was he living anyway, the Gaaue?

Manx: Ec y toshiaght v’eh cummal ayns Balley Keeill Yude (row?) v’eh ny haaue ayns shen as va dooinney gobbraghey marish Martin
English: At the beginning he was living in St Judes (was he?) he was a smithy there and there was a man working with him Martin

Manx: as ta shoh lane scanshoil va’n jeshaght beaynee çheet er yn ellan ec y traa shen haink yn eie shoh ass y America,
English: and this is very important there was a mowing machine coming on the island at that time, this idea came from America,

Manx: v’eh giarey faiyr as va cabbyl ny ghaa tayrn y lhied as ren yn Gaaue as Martin jeshaght dauesyn hene ass yiarn
English: it was cutting grass and a horse or two were pulling it and the Gaaue and Martin made a machine for themselves out of iron

Manx: as v’ad smooinaghtyn er y chooish as v’ad jannoo pattanyn ass napinyn as fuygh, as reddyn myr shen,
English: and they were thinking about it and they were making patterns out of turnips and wood, and things like that,

Manx: as v’ad cur ooilley ny patttyn ayns poagey, daa phoagey, as v’ad goaill dagh ooilley nhee erskyn y clieau dys Gelling’s Foundry ayns Doolish
English: and they were putting all the patterns in a bag, two bags, and they were taking everything over the mountain to Gelling’s Foundry in Douglas

Manx: as hug Gelling’s Foundry yiarn ass ooilley ny pattanyn shoh as ghow ad yn stoo shen erash dys Balley keeill Yude
English: and Gelling’s Foundry produced iron from all these patterns and they took that stuff back to St Judes

Manx: as ren ad yn chied beayneee dauseyn hene ayns shen as va ny focklyn Neen as Martin er y toieag, ooilley ass yiarn
English: and they made the first mower for themselves there and the words Neen and Martin on the seat, all made of iron

Manx: as va’n ghreie shoh caillit rish bleeantyn as va’n ven gobbraghey da’n thie-tashtee...Paaie Killip ass Laksaa
English: and the machine was lost for years and the woman working for the museum...Paaie Killip from Lezayre

Manx: as v’ee ny ben yindyssagh... as haink ee dooys as dooyrt ee ‘vel enney ayd raad ta’n jeshaght shoh ...yn jeshaght beaynee Neen as Martin?’
English: and she was a wonderful woman...and she came to me and she said ‘Do you know where this machine is...the machine “Neen and Martin”?’

Manx: As dreggyr mee as cha sym c’raad t’eh... as ansherbee hie ee mygeayrt ooilley ny magheryn as heill ee dy row sorçh dy chullee quaagh ayns ny dressyn
English: And I answered that I didn’t know where it is...and anyway she went all around the fields and she thought there was some strange equipment in the bushes

Manx: ayns boayl enmyssit ‘Bill Willy’s jus er-gerrey da Jurby. As haink ee dooys un laa as dooyrt ee... hooar mee yn jeshaght beaynee shoh
English: in a place called ‘Bill Willy’s just near Jurby. And she came to me one day and said...I found this mowing machine

Manx: ayns ny dressyn ayns lhieenee Bill Willy ...as hie mee ayns yn tayrneyder ayms as trailer as hooar mee eh ayns shen
English: in the bushes in Bill Willy’s fields...and I went with my tractor and trailer and I found it there

Manx: as ghow mee er ash da’n gowaltys as ren mee glenney magh dagh ooilley nhee as cur ooill ayn ayns dagh ooilley nhee
English: and I took it back to the field and I cleaned out everything and put oil in everything

Manx: as...va’n slat er-gerrey da feer vergagh as v’eh bunnys brishey ayns y çheshvean as hug mee fuygh er y chooyll as kuse dy voltyn ayn dy ‘reayll jeeragh eh
English: and...the rod was almost very rusty and it was nearly breaking in the middle and I put wood on the back and some bolts in it to keep it straight

Manx: ... as my ta shiu son cur shilley er yn jeshaght shoh t’eh ec y ‘Groove’ (vel?) She. T’eh foast ayn ayns corneil... cha nel eh jeshaght feer vooar eddyr...
English: ...and if you want to visit this machine, it is at the Grove (is it?) Yes. It is still there in a corner...it is not a very big machine at all...

Manx: t’eh foast ayn as oddagh oo jeeaghyn er Neen as Martin er...as ta shen yn jeshaght smoo scanshoil ayns Mannin as v’eh er ny hroggal ayns Balley Keeill Yude ec y cheirdee ayns shen ec y Ghaaue as y dooinney shoh Martin.
English: it’s still there and you can see Neen and Martin on it...and that is the most important machine in Mannin and it was built in St Judes at the smithy by the Gaaue and this man Martin.

Manx: As Lhisagh oo goll dy chur shilley er as jean shickyr dy vel eh ayns cooish mie.
English: And you should go to visit it and make sure that it is in good shape.

Manx: Nee’m shen
English: I’ll do that.

Manx: Shen feer scanshoil
English: It’s very important.

Manx: As bwooise dy Jee dy row yn ven shoh ass yn thie tashtee ronsaghey mygeayrt dy gheddyn greim er
English: And thanks to God that this woman from the museum was searching around to get hold of it

Manx: As t’eh ayns shen foast
English: And it’s still there yet.

Manx: As lurg shen hie eh dys Jurby, as v’eh gobbragh ayns y Lhen, as va keirdee ayns shen er-gerrey da’n awin as t’eh foast ayn agh t’eh jus tholtan ec y traa t’ayn
English: And after that he went to Jurby, and he was working at the Lhen, and there was a smithy there near the river and it is still there but it’s just a ruin at the moment

Manx: as lurg shen tra v’eh ny haaue as doal hie eh dys thie elley ayns ny Curraghan... (ny Curraghan dooyrt eh) as v’eh ayn y thie shen
English: and after that when he was retired and blind he went to another house in the Curragh...(Curraghyn he said) and he was in that house

Manx: tra va shin goll dy chur shilley er, son yn chooid smoo.
English: when we were visiting him for the most part.

Manx: Dooinney braew as yindyssagh as va ram skeealyn echey ayns ny cassetteyn loayrt mychione crou cabbil as ooilley yn obbyr v’eh jannoo,
English: A fine, wonderful man and he had loads of stories on cassettes talking about shoeing horses and all the work he was doing,

Manx: as cha row eh coontey monney jeh ny h-eirinee, dooyrt ad, agh cha nel ad gobbragh v’eh ooilley ny Gaauenyn ta gobbragh,
English: and he wasn’t thinking much of the farmers, they said, but they aren’t working, it was all the Smithies who are working,

Manx: as v’ad gobbragh voish bunnys hoght er y chlag sy voghree derrey dy daink y dorraghys er yn oie (laa liauyr)... laa rouyr,
English: and they were working from about eight in the morning until the darkness came at night (a long day)...too long a day,

Manx: as v’ad cho schleioil... greieyn laueyn echey as cho schleioil whooinney as gynsaghey voish ny shenn deiney v’ayn tra v’eh eshyn ...
English: and they were so skilful...his hand-tools, and so skilful, yessir, and learning from the old men who were there when he was

Manx: cha row agh jus ny phaitçhey. V’ad mie erskyn towse.
English: only a child. They were fantastic.

Manx: Row uss ruggit as troggit er y twoaie ansherbee? C’raad v’ou ruggit whooinney?
English: Were you born and brought up in the north anyway? Where were you born yessir?

Manx: Va mee ruggit ayns Ballacurrie....as my ayr as my henn ayr, cha row my shenn ayr ruggit agh ayns Skylley Maayl
English: I was born in Ballacurrie...and my father and grandfather, my grandfather was only born in Michael.

Manx: Ta mee braew ynsit jus er y çheer shoh, cha nel mee jannoo monney dy hroailtys nish, cha nel my ven agh çhing as cha nel ee goll magh monney.
English: I am well educated just on this land, I am not doing much travelling now, my wife is ill and she doesn’t go out much.

Manx: C’raad v’ou goll dys scoill ansherbee?
English: Where were you going to school anyway?

Manx: Hie mee dys y scoill ec y Vunchan...v’eh feer quaagh yn skeeal shoh.
English: I went to school at the Buchan...it was very strange this story.

Manx: Agh va my naunt ayns Sostyn as hooar e sheshey baase as haink ee dy veaghey ayns Balley Chashtal ayns thie enmyssit ‘Fighfield’ ec y traa shen... va goll jeeragh voish Bowring Road dys y çhooylaghyn as v’ee beaghey ayns y chorneil shen.
English: But my aunt was in England and her husband died and she came back to live in Castletown in a house called ‘Fighfield’ at that time...which went directly from Bowring Road to the promenade and she was living in that corner.

Manx: As va daa ‘neen as mac eck as v’adsyn goll dys y Vuchan as dooyrt ee ta mee shirrey er argid er yn oyr nagh row monney eck as dooyrt ee rish my ayr as my voir ‘by vie lhieu cur kied da ny paitçhyn eu çheet dy veaghey marym pene as oddagh ad goll dys y scoill cheddin’
English: She had two daughters and a son and they were going to the Buchan and she said I am looking for some money as she didn’t have much and she said to my father and my mother ‘would you like to give permission for your children to live with me and they would be able to go to the same school’

Manx: as dooyrt ad myr shen as va shin cur argid da’n ven shoh, cha nel row monney er-lhiam pene...da’n thie shoh...as v’ad goll dys y scoill cheddin.
English: and they said OK and we were giving money to this woman, not much I reckon...to this house...and they were going to the same school.

Manx: V’eh feer vie er yn oyr...va mee gynsaghey mychione argid as reddyn myr shen. Tra va shin beaghey er y çheer cha row shin jannoo ymmyd jeh argid, cha row veg dy chionnaghey as reddyn myr shen
English: It was very good because...I was learning about money and things like that. When we were living in the country we weren’t making use of money, there wasn’t anything to buy and things like that

Manx: as tra va mee er y çhooylaghyn shid va shin goll dy chionnaghey arran as stoo myr shen voish ben as y çhapp eck er y çhooylaghyn as va’n ennym eck Bnr Brown; ta’n çhapp ecksh ersooyl dy bollagh nish.
English: and when I was on that promenade we were going to buy bread and things like that from a woman and her shop was on the promenade and her name was Mrs Brown; her shop is gone completely now.

Manx: As va shin goll dys shen dagh laa as va my naunt cur argid dooys as va shen yn chied cheayrt dy row mee jannoo ymmyd jeh argid as coontaghyn as reddyn myr shen, feer vie.
English: And we were going there each day and my aunt was giving money to me and that was the first time I was using money and accounts and things like that, very good.

Manx: Va’n Balley Chashtal yn ard valley ec y traa shen dooys as v’eh feer vie as va mee loayrt rish sleih nagh row mee loayrt rish er y twoaie.
English: Castletown was the top place at that time to me and it was very good and I was speaking to people that I wasn’t speaking to in the north.

Manx: Row oo maynrey cummal ayns Balley Chashtal?
English: Were you happy living in Castletown?

Manx: Maynrey...va mish...boayl feer vie. Va’n scoill shen foddee ny share na scoill ayms ayns shoh as va ard-ven ayn, yn ard-venainshtyr, feer vie, as v’ee freayll rick er dagh ooilley nhee
English: Happy...I was...a very good place. The school there was perhaps better than my school here and there was a top woman there, the headmistress, very good, and she was keeping an eye on everything

Manx: as va scoill feer vie ec y traa shen. As traa va mee girree magh ass shen hie mee dys yn Olloo-scoill
English: and the school was very good at that time. And when I left there I went to the University(?)

Manx: C’raad?
English: Where?

Manx: Balley Chashtal...Ree Illiam as veih shen hie mee dys y Navy
English: Castletown...King William’s and from there I went to the Navy.

Manx: Va caggey ayn as va tree reddyn dy smooinaghtyn er tra va shin nyn baitçhyn, yn arm yn navy as y RAF, as shen ooilley.
English: There was the war and there were three things to think about when we were children, the army, navy and the RAF, and that’s all.

Manx: As va mee graihagh er yn cheayn as dooyrt mee rhym pene hem dys yn Navy as va mee ersooyl rish bleeantyn ayns y chaggey goll mygeayrt.
English: And I loved the sea and I said to myself I’ll go to the Navy and I was away for years in the war going around.

Manx: Haink mee ny quaiyl kuse dy Vanninee tra va mee ersooyl.
English: I met several Manxmen when I was away.

Manx: As ta mee er lhiah yn skeeal shoh roie er-lhiam pene kuse dy chassetteyn er lhiam pene
English: And I have read this story before I reckon on several cassettes myself

Manx: agh tra va mee ayns Austrail ayns Sydney va mee fo gee my yinnair as va coraa voish’n lout ‘Vel Manninagh ayns shoh erbee?’ ayns Baarle,
English: but when I was in Australia in Sydney I was just eating my dinner and there was a voice from the loft saying ‘Is there any Manxman here?’ in English,

Manx: as dreggyr mee ‘son shickyrys quoi t’ayn?’ as dooyrt eh ‘dooinney enmyssit Kennaw’
English: and I replied ‘for certain, who’s there?’ and he said ‘a man called Kennaw’

Manx: as dreggyr mee ‘cha nel shiuiush ny Manninagh edyr’ as dooyrt mee ‘trooid dys shoh, tar neose yn aarey dy heet my whaiyl’ as haink eh dys y voayrd
English: and I replied ‘You’re not a Manxman at all’ and I said ‘come on in, come down the ladder to meet me’ and he came to the table

Manx: as va shin loayrt ry-cheilley as dreggyr mee ‘cre yn oyr dy vel shiu enmyssit Kennaw?’ as dreggyr eh ta Kennaugh yn ennym kiart ayms
English: and we were talking together and I asked ‘Why are you called Kennaw?’ and he replied that Kennaugh is my correct name

Manx: agh neayrs va mee cur my chass er y çheer shoh v’ad ooiley gra Kennaw as ta eer my vac hene enmyssit Kennaw
English: but ever since I put my foot on this land they were all saying Kennaw and even my son is called Kennaw

Manx: well dreggyr mee, ‘cha nel shen red erbee...ta blass Manninagh ayd ansherbee’
English: well I said, ‘that’s not important...you have a Manx accent anyway’

Manx: as dooyrt eh ‘by vie lhiat cur kishtey da my vooinjerey ayns Purt ny h-Inshey tra ta shiu goll erash dys Mannin?’
English: and he said ‘would you like to give a box to my relatives in Peel when you are going back to Mannin?’

Manx: as dreggyr me ‘by vie lhiam’ as hug eh kishtey son toyrtys dy chur erash da ny mooinjerey echey ayns Purt ny h-Inshey
English: and I replied ‘I would’ and he gave me a box of presents to give back to his relatives in Peel

Manx: as v’ad beaghey ayns thie beg er-gerrey da’n vayr dys Glion Maye.
English: and they were living in a small house near the road to Glen Maye.

Manx: As ec yn nah cheayrt dy row mee ayns Mannin hie mee er my roar dys Purt ny h-Inshey as yn kishtey shoh
English: And the next time that I was in Mannin I went on my bike to Peel with this box

Manx: as hooar mee yn thie as dooyrt mee rish yn mooinjerey echey va ayns shoh ta shoh toyrtys voish Mnr Kennaw ass Sydney ayns Austrail
English: and I found the house and I said to his people there: ‘This is a gift from Mr. Kennaw from Sydney in Australia’

Manx: as v’ad jeant magh lesh - va pot-tey - er-lhiam pene as kuse dy skaalyn as cappanyn, v’ad seyr ec y traa shen
English: and they were very pleased - there was a teapot I think and several saucers and cups, they were free at that time

Manx: as dooyrt ad rhym ‘vel oo goll erash dys yn Austrail?’ as dreggyr mee ‘foddee’
English: and they said to me ‘Are you going back to Australia?’ and I answered ‘possibly’

Manx: as dooyrt ad ‘by vie lhiat cur toyrtys da Mnr Kennaw ayns shen?’ As dreggyr mee ‘kiart dy liooar shen yn red y yannoo’
English: and they said ‘Would you like to give a present to Mr. Kennaw there?’ And I replied ‘certainly, that’s the thing to do’

Manx: as ren mee myr shen as hug mee kishtey elley da Mnr Kennaw as va goll er myr shen.
English: and I did so and I gave another box to Mr. Kennaw and it went on like that.

Manx: Va ben beaghey ec thie enmyssit (s’cummey). Hig ee erash dooys ec bunnys tree er y chlag sy voghree
English: There was a woman living at a house called (it doesn’t matter). It will come back to me at about three o’clock in the morning

Manx: ...as chellvaney mayrt
English: ...and I’ll telephone you

Manx: Jean shen whooinney – gura mie ayd
English: Do that yessir – thanks

Manx: As yn nah hooill eck, As oddagh ee jeeaghyn er red ennagh va çheet dy heet whooinney...oddagh ee.
English: And she had second sight, and she could see anything that was going to happen yessir...she could.

Manx: Va’n ennym eck Ellen Brew. V’ee shenn ven, braew coar as yindyssagh. As v’ee cur dooys shey pingyn nish as reesht tra va mee çheet ny quail
English: Her name was Ellen Brew. She was an old woman, fine, decent and wonderful. She used to give me six pence now and again when I met her

Manx: as v’ee cur yn laue orrym myr shoh as v’ee ginsh dou tra va son çheet orrym as cha row mee coontey monney jeh shen.
English: and she was putting her hand on me like this and telling me what was going to happen to me, and I wasn’t thinking much of it.

Manx: Ansherbee, shen ee, gagh cheayrt va mee çheet ny quail as v’ee ceau ram argid as v’ee ny ben boght whooinney.
English: Anyway, that’s her, each time I met her she was spending a lot of money though she was a poor woman yessir.

Manx: Ansherbee, tra va mee ayns Sydney va stoyr ayn, mooar erskyn towse, as va ram stoo goll erash dys Sostyn seyr, cha row eh son veg.
English: Anyway, when I was in Sydney there was a store there, extremely large, and there was a lot of stuff going back to England free, it cost nothing.

Manx: Oddagh oo kionnaghey kishtey myr shen lum lane jeh bee as reddyn va goan agglagh er y çheer shoh er coontey yn chaggey.
English: You could buy a box like that full of food and things that were terribly scarce in this country because of the war.

Manx: As va mee smooinaghtyn mychione Ellen Brew as chionnee mee kishtey mooar jeh shen jeh stainnaghyn soo as feill vart as dagh ooilley nhee myr shen
English: And I was thinking about Ellen Brew and I bought a big box of that, of tins of juice and corned beef and every sort of thing like that

Manx: ayns stainnaghyn as red erbee va goan ayns Goal va mee cur stiagh ayns y chishtey shoh as hug mee ad, cha dug mee ad,
English: in tins and anything that was scarce in Britain I was putting into this box and I sent them, I didn’t carry them,

Manx: hug mee ad ayns sy phost, da’n ven shoh, v’ad seyr, cha row ad costal er chor erbee er coontey jeh’n chiannoortys as jannoo dellal eddyr ad hene...
English: I put them in the post, to this woman, they were free, they didn’t cost anything at all because of the governorship and their arrangement...

Manx: as v’ee coontey monney jeh, coontey mooar jeh shen, v’ee, v’ee as va bee dy liooar tannaghtyn rish shiaghteeyn jeeish ayns shen.
English: and she thought a lot of it, she appreciated it greatly, yes, and there was enough food to last her for weeks there.

Manx: As cha row dagh ooilley nhee olk edyr.
English: And not everything was bad either.

Manx: Cre’n vlein daag oo yn Navy eisht?
English: What year did you leave the navy then?

Manx: Cha sayms...nuy cheead jeig...va’n caggey ec y jerrey...bunnys...queig as daeed foddee. Va mee girree magh ass yn Navy ayns Hong Kong.
English: I don’t know... nineteen hundred...the war was at an end...nearly...45, perhaps. I was leaving the Navy in Hong Kong.

Manx: Hie mee erash myr... jus myr marrinagh ...er Carrier enmyssit ‘Patroller’ er-lhiam pene.
English: I went back just as a mariner...on a Carrier called ‘Patroller,’ I think.

Manx: As tra dirree mee magh as yn Navy cha row obbyr ayms, cha row veg ayms dy yannoo as va dagh ooilley nhee elley v’ad braew ynsit er red ennagh roish my jagh ad stiagh ayn.
English: And when I left the Navy, I didn’t have work, I didn’t have anything to do, and everyone else was well educated in something before they went in.

Manx: Va Dick y Radlagh ayns y vanc roish my jagh eh stiagh as hie eh erash dys y vanc.
English: Dick Radcliffe was in the bank before he went in and he went back to the bank.

Manx: Agh cha row veg ayms as lurg shen cha row veg ayms...cha row keird ayms er red ennagh y yannoo hie mee erash da ny lughtyn...
English: But there wasn’t anything for me and after that there was still nothing...I had no trade at all, so I went back to the companies...

Manx: ayns shen jus jannoo cargo eddyr Mannin as buill elley, New Zealand Shipping Company ve, as hie mee ayns shen rish tammylt, jus dy gheddyn startey.
English: there just doing cargo between Mann and other places, the New Zealand Shipping Company it was, and I went there for a while, just to get started.

Manx: As lurg tammylt va kuse dy lieh geearree magh as ny magheryn ayns shen as va mee able dy heet erash as goaill toshiaght er eirinys
English: And after a while a few people were looking to get out of the fields there, and I was able to come back and start farming

Manx: as va mee my eirinagh lurg shen rish tammylt foddey derrey va mee geearree magh ass yn obbyr shen, va mee ro skee dy yannoo eh.
English: and I was a farmer after that for a long while until I wanted out of that work, I was too tired to do it.

Manx: C’raad v’ou gobbraghey er ny magheryn? Jus ayns yn twoaie son y chooid smoo?
English: Where were you working on the fields? Just here in the north for the most part?

Manx: Er yn eirinys? Jus er y voal shoh
English: On the farming? Just here on this place.

Manx: Va ollagh ayms. Va mee cur kied dou dy vreh ram lheiy ayn as va mee cur kied dou dy hughey voish ny booaghyn as tra v’ad bunnys blein dy eash va goll er creck ec y abattoir.
English: There was cattle with me. I was helping to birth many calves and helping them on from the cows, and when they were about a year old they were sold at the abattoir.

Manx: Shen yn cheird v’aym’s ec y traa shen as va mee gollrish ny shenn Vanninee ooilley, goaill toshiaght er y cheean as erash er y thalloo reesht as croit oc.
English: That was my trade at that time, and I was like all the old Manx people, starting out at sea and then back on the land again with a croft.

Manx: Shen yn obbyr ayms. As va sym mooar ayms er çhengey as tra ooilley
English: That’s my work. And I always had a great interest in the language

Manx: Vel oo foast goll er yn eeastagh er chore erbee...nish as neesht?
English: Are you still going fishing now and again?

Manx: Row oo sy traie chaie? Row oo goll er yn eeastagh?
English: Were you previously? Going fishing?

Manx: Va baatey beg ayms. Va shin goll magh er yn eeastagh nish as reesht marish sleih gollrish Illiam y Radlagh.
English: I had a small boat. We were going out fishing now and again with people like Illiam Radcliffe.

Manx: As va mee nish as reesht mooie ayns Baaie Rhumsaa ayns my vaatey hene as va baatey elley ayn
English: And I was now and again out in Ramsey Bay in my own boat and there was another boat there

Manx: as cheayll mee ram sleih gyllagh orrym as va ooilley y Ghaelg ayn...ram boghtynid...as quoi va’n agh Doolish y Karagher, Illiam y Radlagh as Walter y Chleree as kuse dy lieh myr shen ooilley ayns yn un vaatey.
English: and I heard many people calling out to me and it was all in Manx...lots of rubbish...and who was there but Doug Faragher, Illiam Radcliffe, and Walter Clarke and several others all in one boat.

Manx: As va’n Ghaelg goll...rish ooryn eddyr ain hene as y baatey elley...ta baatey foast ayms as cha nel mee goll magh dy monney...dy mennick nish.
English: And there was Manx going on...for hours between ourselves and the other boat...I still have a boat and I’m not going out much...often now.

Manx: Agh cha nel caa ayms er yn oyr dy vel my ven cho ching. Ta graih ayms goll magh ass.
English: But I don’t have the opportunity because my wife is so ill. I love going out.

Manx: As nish as reesht va mee goll magh ass marish Juan y Curleod as v’eh graihagh er goll er... y Killick, as Callig v’ad gra yn chooid smoo jeu.
English: And now and again I was going out with Juan Corlett and he loved going after...the Killick, and Callig they mostly say.

Manx: Callig er y jiass as Killick er y twoaie as v’eh mie ynsit er yn eeastagh shen as t’eh goll er gerrey da ny creggyn as va enmyn er Juan er ooilley ny baieyn as creggyn ayns shen as Gaelg orroo.
English: Callig in the south and Killick in the north and he was well versed in that fishing and he goes near to the rocks and Juan had names for all the bays and rocks there in Manx.

Manx: Sleih gollrish Illiam Pat y Radlagh as va mee jeeaghyn ersyn dy mennick. As Charles Mooar. Agh va Illiam Pat y Radlagh beaghey ayns Rhumsaa as va brastyl echey as va mee goll dy chur shilley ersyn
English: People like Illiam Pat Radcliffe and I was watching him often. And Charles Mooar. But Illiam Pat Radcliffe was living in Ramsey and he had a class and I was going to visit him

Manx: as goll dys y vrastyl echey nish as reesht. As va Illiam mie ynsit er y grammar as feer vie myr fer-ynsee as myr shen.
English: and going to his class now and again. And Illiam was well versed in grammar and an excellent teacher and so on.

Manx: As ec y toshiaght va shin cummal brastyl ec y Scoill Grammar ayns Rhumsaa as va orrin dy eeck argid da’n wardoon ayn shen...well kiart dy liooar as lurg tammylt ghoon ad y vrastyl shen
English: At the beginning we were holding a class at the Grammar School in Ramsey and we had to pay some money to the warden there...well fair enough, and after a while they closed that class

Manx: as va orrin goll dys boayl erbee elley as hie shin dys thie-oast yn ‘Ree Bretin’ er y çhooylaghyn ayns Rhumsaa as va shen feer vie.
English: and we had to go somewhere else and we went to the pub ‘The Welsh King’ on the promenade in Ramsey and that was very good.

Manx: As va shin ooilley nyn soie mygeayrt boayrd as beggan dy yough ain as feer vie...as Y Ghaelg ny smoo flaaoil lurg yn vrastyl na ec y toshiaght whooinney. Nagh row?
English: And we were all sitting around a table and had a little drink and it was very good...and the Manx was more fluent after the class than at the beginning yessir. Wasn’t it?

Manx: Foddee
English: Perhaps

Manx: Un cheayrt va shin loayrt ass y Ghaelg ayns shen as haink y ven as ny smoo jough ayn as v’ee geaishtagh rish yn Ghaelg as dooyrt ee ‘are you ones of the trawlers?’
English: One time we were speaking in Manx there and this woman came along with more drink and she was listening to the Manx and she said ‘are you ones of the trawlers?’

Manx: As dreggyr shin, cha nel shin er chor erbee, ta shin jus nyn Manninee as dooyrt shin dy row shin ass yn Loghlyn, boayl erbee elley myr shen
English: And we replied, not at all, we are just Manxmen and we said that we were from Norway, or some other place like that.

Manx: Va ram sleih smooinaghtyn myr shen
English: A lot of people thought like that

Manx: As ec y traa shen va shin ooilley gra ta feme ain er boayl erbee dy ynsagh Gaelg as dy reayll lioaryn as dagh ooilley nhee myr shen
English: And at that time we were all saying that we needed a place to learn Manx and to keep books and everything like that

Manx: as va shin ooilley jeeaghyn mygeayrt nyn mooin er boayl elley as traa...Sheshaght Ynsee faagail y thie shoh dooyrt mee rhym pene ‘nish ta caa ain’
English: and we were all looking around us for another place and when the Education Society left this house I said to myself ‘now this is our opportunity’

Manx: as va shin loayrt trooid yn leighder ayms dys y Voayrd Ynsee mychione kionnaghey y voayl shoh da’n çhengey as cha row ad lane arryltagh ec y toshiaght
English: and we were speaking through my lawyer to the Education Board about buying this place for the language and they were not really willing at the beginning

Manx: as v’ad ooilley gra, well lhisagh y boayl shoh ve kiart dy liooar da ram sheshaghtyn elley as dreggyr mee... cha nhegin...ta shin shirrey er y voayl shoh da’n çhengey
English: and they were all saying, well, this place should be good enough for many other organisations and I answered...not at all...we are seeking this place for the language

Manx: as kied dooin da cur kied da sleih elley ...sheshaghyn elley... dy reayll ymmyd jeh er nyn sonsyn.
English: and permission for us to give permission to other people...other organisations...to make use of it for them.

Manx: Ec y jerrey lurg kiare bleeaney... ren ad... row(?) ad arryltagh dy yannoo ooilley shen as ren ad cur kied dooin dy yannoo ymmyd jeh as fo vaayl
English: At the end, after four years...they did... they were willing to do all that and they gave us permission to use it under lease

Manx: as va’n maayl feer injil as v’eh orrin ooilley dy reayll rick er y troggal shoh, dy reaghey ooilley ny h-uinniagyn as reddyn myr shen.
English: and the rent was very low and we all had to keep an eye on this building, to arrange all the windows and things like that.

Manx: Ec yn toshiaght v’eh orrin dy aa-yannoo ooilley ny h-uinniagyn shoh as ta shen fuinneg noa....fuinneoig ta ny Yernee gra.
English: At the beginning we had to replace all these windows and that one is a new window... ‘fuinneoig’ the Irish say.

Manx: As va argid yn lane boirey...agh va sheshaght goll er enmyssit ‘yn çhengey vio’ as ta shen son çhymsaghey argid er son yn çhengey
English: And the money was a big worry...but there was an organisation called ‘yn çhengey vio’ (the living language) that was to raise money for the language

Manx: as va shin jannoo kiart dy liooar lesh y voayl shoh ec y toshiaght as va mish my wardoon ec y çheshaght as va mee abyl dy reayll rick er voish y thie ayms
English: and we were doing well enough with this place at the beginning and I was warden of the organisation and I was able to keep an eye on it from my house

Manx: as va ram lioaryn goll er creck dys boayl erbee sy theihll shoh wass whooinney as ram obbyr ayms dy-yannoo as va shin jannoo ram obbyr reaghey dagh ooilley nhee
English: and there were many books being sold to anywhere in this world yessir, and there was a lot of work for me to do and we were doing a lot of work arranging everything

Manx: As va shin shirrey er argid dy chur lectraghys ayn noa-emshyragh, as ny çhiasseyderyn ayn er yn oyr dy row shenn chuirrey ayn
English: And we were looking for money to put in modern electricity, and the heaters, because there was an old boiler there

Manx: as ec y toshiaght, va geayll ayn dy yannoo ymmyd jeh son yn çhiass as haink eh dy ve .....as va jannoo ymmyd jeh ooill
English: and at the start, there was coal to use for the heat and it came to be...and then they were using oil

Manx: as va shen yn stoo v’ad jannoo ymmyd jeh tra va mish freayll rick er as va seck mooar ayn fer jeh ny shamyrn ayns shen.
English: and those were the things they were using when I was keeping watch and there was a big sack in one of the rooms there.

Manx: As va shin jannoo ymmyd jeh ooilley yn argid voish ‘yn çhengey vio’ dy eeck son ny çhiasseyderyn shoh as ooilley yn lectraghys
English: And we were using all the money from ‘yn çhengey vio’ to pay for these heaters and all the electricity

Manx: as va ny shenn coirraghyn ayns stayd agglagh as dooyrt ad ta feme erriu er dagh ooilley nhee jeant as y noa
English: and the old boilers were in a terrible state and they said that you need to have everything replaced and made new.

Manx: Ta dagh ooilley nhee reaghit nish as ta wardoon ayns y Donnag as ta’n ennym echey ec y traa t’ayn Lee Quaggin as y ven echey Angela...ben feer vie... as yn oikan oc ‘oinkan’ t’ad gra er y jiass, nagh vel, oikan oc enmyssit Calum as t’eh bunnys daa ny tree bleeaney d’eash.
English: Everything is arranged now and there is a warden at the Donnag and he is called, at the moment, Lee Quaggin, and his wife Angela...a very nice woman...and their child ‘child’ they say in the south, don’t they? A child called Calum and he is nearly two or three years old.

Manx: Quoi s’lesh yn Donnag ansherbee?
English: Who owns the Donnag anyway?

Manx: Well, va shen lesh yn lught ayms yn Donnag as keayrt dy row v’eh thie-thooit as v’eh sorçh dy thie-oast... as va’n çhenn ennym er ‘The Brown Cow’ thie-oast.
English: Well, that was my family’s, the Donnag, and once it was a thatched house and sort of an inn...and the old name on it was ‘The Brown Cow’ Inn.

Manx: As va ram sleih goll mygeayrt as shooyl ec y traa shen...shen tammylt er dy henney nish...as tra va frassyn ayn v’eh orroo dy chronkal er y dorrys dy gheddyn boayl dy lhie ayns lout ennagh fo clea as va jough ayn, lhune, cha row monney dy ushtey goll er bunnys ooilley jough
English: And there were a lot of people going about and walking at that time...that’s a long time ago now...and when it rained they had to knock on the door to get somewhere to lie down in some loft under the roof, and there was drink available, indeed there wasn’t much water going, almost all drink

Manx: as shen yn oyr dy vel ee thie-oast v’ayn as haink dooinney dy veaghey ayns shen as v’eh dooinney sheelt eh as dooyrt eh cha nel mee coontey monney jeh yn Brown Cow ec kione my dooyrt eh as v’eh slaa dagh ooilley nhee lesh yeeal
English: and that’s the reason it was an inn and a man came to live there and he was a sober man and he said ‘I don’t think much of the Brown Cow at all’ he said, and he was painting everything with lead

Manx: as v’eh dollit dy bollagh agh tra haink frassyn fliaghey whooinney va ooilley ny focklyn shoh ry-akin trooid y yeeayl, Brown Cow’ as va sleih goll shaghey jannoo spotçhyn as cha row yn dooinney sheelt coontey monney jeh shen
English: and it was all blotted out completely but when a shower of rain came, yessir, all these words could be seen through the lead, ‘Brown Cow’, and people passing by were making jokes, and the sober man wasn’t thinking much of that

Manx: as dooyrt eh shegin dou geddyn rick orroo as va screebeyr echey as va ooilley yn yeeal screebit voish kione y thie as The Brown Cow bollit dy bollagh as va shen kiart dy liooar
English: and he said ‘I must sort them out’ and he had a scraper and he scraped all the lead from the top of the house and The Brown Cow was completely erased, and that was good enough.

Manx: As va dooinney elley ayn as e ven ayn as va’n dooinney shoh enmyssit....çhellvaney mayrt ec tree er y chlag sy voghree whooinney
English: And there was another man there and his wife there and this man was called...I’ll telephone you at three o’clock in the morning, yessir

Manx: Va dooinney shoh gobbraghey er ny mwyllin bree va goll mygeayrt er y çheer bwoailley corkey as lheid my shen as yn ven echey feer choar
English: This man was working on the steam mills that went around the countryside threshing corn and such, and his wife was very kind

Manx: as v’ee jannoo awree as reddyn myr shen da ny paitçhyn ayns y scoill as v’ad geddyn jough jeh awree çheh as broit çheh ayns.. ny emshyryn keoie as feayr
English: and she was making soup and things like that for the children in the school and they were getting a drink of hot soup and hot broth in wild and cold weather

Manx: as v’ee jannoo feer vie myr shen cooney lesh ny paitçhyn as v’ee creck kianglagh ny braaghyn va goll er ec y traa shen as v’ee kionnaghey thombaaghey dauesyn va jannoo jough
English: and she was doing very well thus helping the children and she was selling shoe laces that were going at that time and she was buying tobacco for those who made drink

Manx: as va ram jeu ayn as v’ee jannoo obbyr myr shen as fy-yerrey hoal haink yn dooinney as ben elley ayns shen as v’ad jus beaghey ayns shid
English: and there were many of them and she was doing work like that and at long last a man and another woman came there and they were just living there

Manx: as haink yn eash dy ve orroo as v’ad ro-henn dy reayll rick er y thie as dy veaghey ayns shen as hie ad magh dys Rhumsaa dys boayl er-lheh
English: and old age came upon them and they were too old to keep an eye on the house and to live there and they went out to Ramsey to a special place

Manx: ayn raad v’ad cur rick orroo as va’n thie shen follym as v’eh follym ec bunnys yn traa cheddin as chossyn yn Çheshaght Ghailckagh yn thie shoh
English: where they would be looked after and that house was empty and it was empty at about the same time as the Manx Society acquired this house

Manx: as dooyrt mee... bee shen thie, boayl yindyssagh da wardoon as va mee shirrey er dooinney son wardoon dy reayll rick er y thie
English: and I said...this will be a house, a wonderful place for a warden, and I was looking for a man as a warden to keep an eye on the house

Manx: as ec y traa shen hooar ben Leslie Cuirk baase as va Leslie lane trimshagh as v’eh beaghey ayns thie beg dy lheh ayns shen ayns Purt Çhiarn
English: and at that time Leslie Quirk’s wife died and Leslie was very downcast and he was living in a small special house there in Port Erin

Manx: as hellvane mee er Leslie as dooyrt me eshyn ‘S’treih lhiam clashtyn mychione baase dy ven Leslie, agh by vie lhiat beggan dy obbyr dy yannoo?’
English: and I telephoned Leslie and I said to him ‘I’m sorry to hear about your wife’s death, Leslie, but would you like a little work to do?’

Manx: as dreggyr eh, ‘cre yn sorch dy obbyr’, bit beg croutagh, as dooyrt mee ‘ta mee shirrey er dooinney dy veaghey ayns y thie shoh dy reayll rick er Thie ny Gaelgey ry-hoi ny Manninee’
English: and he replied, ‘what sort of work?’ a little crafty, and I said, ‘I’m looking for a man to live in this house to keep watch over Thie ny Gaelgey for the Manx people’

Manx: as dreggyr eh, ‘by vie lhiam yn obbyr shen, ta mee lane trimshagh ayns shoh as beg dy yannoo by vie lhiam yn obbyr shoh’, as haink eh er y twoaie as v’eh yn chied wardoon ainyn
English: and he replied, ‘I would like that work, I’m very sad here and have little to do, I would like that job’, and he came to the north and he was our first warden.

Manx: As lane graihagh er yn obbyr agh v’eh...cha row eh mie ynsit er yiarn roit...cast iron...as v’eh
English: And we really loved the work but he was...he wasn’t well taught in handling cast iron...and he was

Manx: dooinney mie lesh oard as va mee cur beggan dy obbyr echey dy yannoo bentyn rish yiarn roit as
English: a good man with a hammer and I was giving him a little work to do involving cast iron and

Manx: v’eh son brishey dagh ooilley nhee as ny yei as ooilley v’eh feer choar as kenjal as ren eh e chooid shoh
English: he was breaking everything but despite it all he was very decent and kind and he did his best

Manx: as v’eh feer vie as yn chied wardoon ec y traa shen as v’eh cooney yindyssagh dooys as dy row ben ayn freayll rick er yn ammyr ayns shen, freayll rick er ny blaaghyn ...yn stoo gaase ayns shen
English: and he was very good and the first warden at that time and he was a wonderful help to me and if there was a woman there keeping an eye on the riverbed there, keeping an eye on the flowers...the things growing there

Manx: yinnagh Leslie çheet magh as pot çheh echey as cappan dy hea as bainney, shugyr as cur stoo myr shen jee eer da my ven hene...
English: Leslie would come out with a hot pot and a cup of tea and milk, sugar and give such things to her even to my own wife...

Manx: v’eh braew coar as kenjal myr shen as dy row dooinney ayn shoh, lectreyr jannoo beggan dy obbyr as dooinney gobbraghey er ny piobyn
English: he was very decent and kind like that and if there was a man here, an electrician doing a bit of work and a man working on the pipes

Manx: yinnagh Leslie çheet magh as cappan dy hea goll, v’eh myr shen.
English: Leslie would come out with a cup of tea going, he was like that.

Manx: As v’eh jannoo e chooid share dy ghiarey yn faiyr as ec y jerrey va ny lurgaghyn echey bit beg moal v’ad geddyn faase as ny glioonyn echey çheet dy ve faase
English: And he was doing his best to cut the grass and at the end his legs were getting a bit slow and weak, and his knees becoming weak

Manx: as v’eh orrym dy gheddyn cullee er-lheh as myr shen oddagh eh soie sheese er as giarrey faiyr er
English: and I had to get a special piece of equipment so he could sit down on it and cut the grass

Manx: as v’eh graihagh erskyn towse er yn obbyr shoh as v’eh giarrey yn aiyr bunnys cho mennick as oddagh eh shen y yannoo
English: and he was extremely fond of this work and he was cutting the grass nearly as often as he could do so

Manx: v’eh graihagh er yn obbyr as ec y jerrey v’eh çheet dy ve ro çhing eer dy yannoo yn obbyr shen as v’ersyn dy gholl erash dys Southlands
English: he loved the work and at the end he was becoming too ill even to do that work and he had to go back to Southlands

Manx: raad hooar eh baase er-lhiam pene ec y jerrey. Hie mee gys yn oanluckey echey as va mee lane trimshagh dy yeeaghyn er baase Leslie
English: where he died I think at the end. I went to his funeral and I was very sad to see Leslie’s death

Manx: as va ram sleih elley myr shen.
English: and there were many people like that.

Manx: Row oo er yn cheayn jiu, ghooinney?
English: Were you on the sea today, man?

Manx: Well, va shinyn, my vac as mee hene. Va shin ooilley mygeayrt yn Cholloo as mygeayrt Purt Çhiarn, derrey mysh tree er y chlag syn astyr va shen. V'eh feer heh sy vaatey jiu.
English: Well, we were, my son and myself. We were all around the Calf and around Port Erin, until about three o'clock in the afternoon, that was. It was very hot in the boat today.

Manx: Foddym toiggal shen.
English: I can understand that.

Manx: Cha row geay ayn as v'eh feer feer heh.
English: There was no wind and it was very, very hot.

Manx: Cre'n traa hie oo magh? Sy voghrey? Ren oo goll magh sy voghrey?
English: What time did you go out? In the morning? Did you go out in the morning?

Manx: Sy voghrey, yeah.
English: In the morning, yeah.

Manx: As c'raad ta'n baatey ayd? Vel eh ayns Purt hiarn ny Purt le Moirrey?
English: And where is your boat? Is it in Port Erin or Port St. Mary?

Manx: Ayns Purt Çhiarn, ayns shoh. Ta mee kinjagh freayll yn baatey ainyn- ta mee er freayll ram jeu as v'ad ooilley freayllt ayns Purt Çhiarn, cha nel ayns Purt le Moirrey. Ta ram birling as y lhied ayns Purt le Moirrey. T'eh feer doillee geddyn magh as geddyn stiagh ayns y purt shen. Ayns Purt Çhiarn t'eh kiart dy liooar.
English: In Port Erin, here. I always keep our boat - I've kept lots of them and they were all kept in Port Erin, not in Port St. Mary. There are lots of yachts and such in Port St. Mary. It's very difficult to get in and out of that port. In Port Erin it's alright.

Manx: So cre hooar oo jiu? Just gimmee?
English: So what did you get today? Just lobsters?

Manx: Gimmee, aye. As kuse dy phartanyn. Cha nel shin freayll ny partanyn gagh laa. Ta shin freayll kuse my row oardagh ain son kuse dy partanyn, shen ooilley. Ta shin ceau ad ersooyl. Cha nel shin marroo ad mannagh vel feme ain orroo.
English: Lobsters, aye. And a few crabs. We don't keep the crabs every day. We keep a few if we have an order for a few crabs, that's all. We throw them away. We don't kill them unless we need them.

Manx: C'raad t'ou creck ny gimmee ansherbee?
English: Where do you sell the lobsters anyway?

Manx: T'ad goll dys dooinney ayns Anglesey. Ta eshyn cur ad gys y Jiass, dys Sostyn er lhiam's, as t'ad ersooyl gys y 'Rank as y Spansh er lhiam's. Ta shin geddyn tooilley argid er nyn son veih'n dooinney shoh.
English: They go to a man in Anglesey. He sends them to the South, to England, I think, and they go to France and Spain, I think. We get more money for them from this man.

Manx: Kys ta'n obbyr ec yn traa t'ayn? Vel reddyn goll dy mie?
English: How is the work at the moment? Are things going well?

Manx: Oh, t'ad goll feer vie. Feer vie ec y traa t'ayn. Emshir braew ayn ansherbee.
English: Oh, it's going very well. Very well at the moment. Fine weather anyway.

Manx: Shen mie dy liooar.
English: That's alright.

Manx: T'eh jannoo yn obbyr ny s'aasey, my t'ou laccal, tra t'eh kune myr shoh.
English: It makes the work easier, if you like, when it's calm like this.

Manx: Quoid ren oo geddyn jiu? Ren oo geddyn ram, or?
English: How many did you get today? Did you get a lot, or?

Manx: Well, cha nel ram, agh ec y traa t'ayn t'ad s'goan, ayns mee voaldyn. Er lhiam's dy vel ad çheet ry cheilley son jannoo oohyn, my t'ou laccal, as t'ad lhie ayns nyn dowllyn as cha nel ad çheet magh. As tra t'eh mee ny jees ry heet t'eh geddyn ny share derrey yn fouyr gys y Nollick. Ta kuse dy ghimmee goll er ny veeghyn shen. Agh ec y traa t'ayn t'ad s'goan.
English: Well, not a lot, but at the moment they are scarce, in May. I think they come together to lay eggs, if you like, and they lie in their holes and don't come out. And in a month or two it gets better until the Autumn and Christmas. There are a few lobsters about in those months. But at the moment they are scarce.

Manx: As vel oo goll er yn eeastagh son red erbee elley or just gimmee?
English: And do you fish for anything else or just lobsters?

Manx: Well, ny keayrtyn ta shin geddyn skeddan, ny keayrtyn, son bite, as geddyn breck varrey as stoo myr shen, as callig. As bleeantyn er dy henney va shinyn geddyn liehbage agh t'ad s'goan ec y traa t'ayn. S'goan t'ad.
English: Well, sometimes we get herring, sometimes, for bait, and get mackerel and things like that, and pollock. And years ago we used to get flatfish but they are scarce now. They're scarce.

Manx: Cre cho foddey as t'ou er ve er yn cheayn, ghooinney? T'ou er ve er yn eeastagh rish bleeantyn as bleeantyn ta mee credjal.
English: How long have you been on the sea, man? You've been fishing for years and years I believe.

Manx: Lhig dooin gra... quoid dy vleeantyn ta mish ec y eeastagh? Foddee daeed bleeantyn ec yn eeastagh, er lhiam's.
English: Let's say... how many years have I been fishing? Probably forty years fishing, I think.

Manx: As cre'n fa ren oo goll er yn eeastagh?
English: And why did you go fishing?

Manx: Ta mish dy kinjagh goit er y eeastagh. Va mee laccal goll gys y eeastagh tra daag mee yn scoill agh dooyrt my phaarantyn, 'Cha bee cosney ad ayns y eeastagh. Bee shiuish foddey ny share goll ersooyl gy mooir dy gheddyn tooilley argid, as foddee bee shiu dty chaptan myr Juan Caine tra ta shiuish ny shinney. Cha daink mee yn ard shen.'
English: I was always taken with fishing. I wanted to go fishing when I left school but my parents said, 'You won't make money fishing. You'd be better going to sea to get more money, and maybe you'll be a captain like Juan Caine when you're older.' I didn't get that high.

Manx: Mie dy liooar. Feer vie. V'ou ruggit as troggit ayns Purt le Moirrey, nagh row?
English: Alright. Very good. You were born and raised in Port St. Mary, weren't you?

Manx: Va mee ruggit ec yn Laare ayns shen er lhiam's. Va boanderey freayll thie ayns shen. Ben enmyssit Crellin v'ee, er lhiam's. V'ee ny boanderey as va mee ruggit ayns y thie ecksh er lhiam's. Cha nel mee shickyr c'raad ta'n thie agh er lhiam's dy vel eh faggys da'n Laare ayns Colby ayns shen. Er lhiam. Benainshter Crellin. Boanderey.
English: I was born at the Level there, I think. A nurse kept a house there. A woman named Crellin, I think. She was a nurse and I was born in her house, I think. I'm not sure where the house is but I think it's near the Level in Colby. I think. Mrs Crellin. A Nurse.

Manx: As cre'n sorch obbyr va'n jishag as ooilley yn lught thie echey jannoo ayns y phurt?
English: And what sort of work did your father and all his family do in the Port?

Manx: Well va my yishag ny daahder ooilley e vea. Va eshyn ec mooir 'sy nah caggey, va shen ooilley, agh va eshyn ny daahder ooilley e vea.
English: Well my father was a painter all his life. He was at sea in the second war, that was all, but he was a painter all his life.

Manx: Agh va my yishag vooar, va sorch dy obbyr quaagh ec y dooinney shen, v'eh jannoo queeylyn ass fuygh. As e ayr neesht, as e ayr, son sheeloghyn as sheeloghyn.
English: But my grandfather, he did a strange sort of work, he made wheels from wood. And his father too, and his father, for generations and generations.

Manx: Ec keayrtyn ta mee smooinaghtyn foddee haink yn ennym ain veih'n keird shen – wheeyllyn.
English: Sometimes I think perhaps our name came from that trade – wheels.

Manx: Shen eh. Cha s'aym's.
English: That's it. I don't know.

Manx: Foddee. Va ooilley ny shenn Vanninee gra 'Wheeyllyn'.
English: Perhaps. All the old Manx people said 'Wheeyllyn'.

Manx: Gyn dooyt erbee.
English: No doubt.

Manx: Cha row ad gra Quillin, v'ad gra Wheeyllyn. Well ta shen, myr ta fys eu, ta shen yn plural jeh queeyl, nagh vel?
English: They didn't say Quillin, they said Wheeyllyn. Well that's, as you know, that's the plural of wheel, isn't it?

Manx: Foddee dy re Willie the Wheels, cha nel mee shickyr, my jishag wooar.
English: Perhaps he was 'Willie the Wheels', I'm not sure, my grandfather.

Manx: Foddee. Foddee dy vel oo kiart.
English: Maybe. Maybe you're right.

Manx: Ta mee er chlashtyn ram eie mychione yn ennym. Ta kuse dy leih gra dy vel Quillin ass y Yernish holly, as kiart dy liooar va'n cowrey jeh'n lught thie ain va shen yn cullyn. Ta sleih elley gra she MacMillan. Cha nel mee shickyr. Myr dooyrt Doolish y Karagher, t'eh caillt.
English: I've heard lots of notions about the name. Some say Quillin is from the Irish 'holly', and rightly our family symbol was the holly. Others say it's MacMillan. I'm not sure. As Douglas Faragher said, it's lost.

Manx: Gyn dooyt erbee. C'raad va shiu ooilley cummal 'sy phurt?
English: No doubt. Where did you all live in the port?

Manx: Va my jishag vooar as my ayr cummal ec y phurt eh hene, as va nyn thie creckit kuse dy vleeantyn er dy henney. Er lhiam's dy vel dooinney ass Yorkshire cummal ayn nish.
English: My grandfather and my father lived in the port itself, and our house was sold a few years ago. I think a man from Yorkshire lives in it now.

Manx: My daink my jishag vooar erash as crankal er y dorrys as haink dooinney ass Yorkshire gys yn dorrys bee eshyn gra, 'Quoi ta shiuish, ghooinney? C'red t'ou jannoo ayns my hie?'
English: If my grandfather came back and knocked on the door and a man from Yorkshire came to the door he would say, 'Who are you, man? What are you doing in my house?'

Manx: Bee enney eu er y thie. Raad va Allan cummal son bleeantyn.
English: You'll know the house. Where Allan lived for years.

Manx: Va three thieyn obbree noi yn thie. Er yn kied 'er va gaaue gobbraghey, as er y nah 'er va my jishag vooar jannoo e wheeyllyn, as er yn trass er, er yn laare syrjey, va dooinney enmyssit Willy Clucas, va eshyn jannoo shiaullyn, whaaley shiaullyn ayns shen. Willie Clucas.
English: There were three workshops next to our house. In the first one a blacksmith worked, in the second one my grandfather made his wheels, and in the third one, on the upper floor, a man called Willie Clucas made sails.

Manx: Va'n thie shen creckit kuse dy vleeantyn er dy henney nish ansherbee.
English: That house was sold a few years ago now anyway.

Manx: Aye, kuse dy vleeantyn. Agh v'eh ayns drogh stayd, ghooinney. V'eh agglagh, ghooinney. Va'n thie eh hene kiart dy liooar agh va ooilley ny thie obbree, v'ad ooilley ayns drogh stayd. Towllyn ayns yn laareyn as ooilley myr shen. V'eh agglagh. V'eh ayns feme jeh argid.
English: Aye, a few years ago. But it was in a bad state, man. It was awful, man. The house itself was alright but all the workshops were in bad condition. Holes in the floors and all that. It was awful. It needed money.

Manx: T'eh creckit nish ansherbee. T'eh ersooyl veih'n lught thie nish.
English: It's sold now anyway. It's left our family now.

Manx: As ren oo goll dy scoill ec scoill Rushen?
English: And did you go to school at Rushen school?

Manx: Scoill Rushen. Bleeantyn er dy henney nish. Daa as three feed bleeantyn er y henney.
English: Rushen School. Years ago now. Sixty two years ago.

Manx: As ren oo goll ersooyl gys Lerphoyl son traenal as yn lhied son goll er yn cheayn?
English: And did you go to Liverpool for training and the like, for going to sea?

Manx: Tra va mee shey jeig hie mee gys Lerphoyl as va mee shiaull ersooyl marish yn Co-lught Harrison, as hie mee gys Lunnin lurg shen as va mee ersooyl gy mooir marish yn Colught yn Rollage Gorrym. As va ram deiney ayns yn colught shen as Gallic oc. Keeadyn jeu. Ooilley ass ny hEllanyn. Va mee geddyn greim er fockle ny ghaa jeh'n Gallic tra va mish ayns Colught yn Rollage Gorrym.
English: When I was sixteen I went to Liverpool and I sailed away with the Harrison Line, and I went to London, and after that I was away at sea with the Blue Star Line. And there were lots of men who spoke Gallic. Hundreds of them. All from the Islands. I learned a word or two of Gallic when I was in the Blue Star Line.

Manx: As row shen greinnaghey uss gynsaghey beggan Gaelg tra v'ou clashtyn yn Gallic goll er loayrt? Row Gaelg ayd ec yn traa shen?
English: And did that encourage you to learn a bit of Manx when you heard Gallic being spoken? Did you know any Manx at that time?

Manx: Well va paart dy Ghaelg aym ec y traa t'ayn. Va mee goaill lioaryn marym tra va mish ersooyl, lhied jeh'n Kied Lessoonyn screeuit ec Goodwin as stoo myr shen. As dooyrt Doolish y Karagher, 'Ta shiuish ny dooiney ynrican ayns y theihll ta gynsaghey yn Ghaelg ayns y China' dooyrt eh, 'As ta mish yn dooinney ynrican ayns yn theihll oddagh loayrt Swahili as Gaelg Vanninagh' Shen myr dooyrt Doolish y Karagher.
English: Well I knew some Manx at that time. I took books with me when I was away, like the First Lessons written by Goodwin and things like that. And Douglas Faragher said, 'You're the only man in the world who is learning Manx in China' he said, 'And I'm the only man in the World who can speak Swahili and Manx Gaelic' That's what Douglas Faragher said.

Manx: Shen eh. Vel oo cooinaghtyn Doolish y Karagher dy mie?
English: That's it. Do you remember Douglas Faragher well?

Manx: Cre shen?
English: What's that?

Manx: Vel oo foast cooinaghtyn yn dooinney hene?
English: Do you still remember the man himself?

Manx: Oh, dy jarroo. Tra va mish ersooyl ec mooir va mee screeu rish yn dooinney shen, as va eshyn gra, 'Tra ta shiuish ayns yn Ellan hig gys my hie as gynsaghey beggan tooilley Gaelg' Va eshyn slane goit ec yn Ghaelg, ghooinney. As s'bastagh dy dooar yn dooinney baase tra v'eh, well cha row eh ro henn ansherbee.
English: Oh, indeed. When I was away at sea I used to write to him, and he said, 'When you're on the Island come to my house and learn a bit more Manx.' He was completely fascinated by Manx, man. And it's a shame that he died when, well he wasn't that old anyway.

Manx: Aye, s'bastagh nagh vel eh ayn yn laa t'ayn jiu son fakin ooilley'n sleih loayrt.
English: Aye, it's a shame that he isn't here today to see all the people speaking Manx.

Manx: Veagh shen jannoo foays da e chree. Bee shickyr dy shen.
English: That would have gladdened his heart. Be sure of that.

Manx: As t'ou cooinaghtyn Ned Maddrell.
English: And you remember Ned Maddrell.

Manx: Va mee currit gys e thie dy jannoo coloayrtys marish yn dooinney shen agh va mee ro faitagh. Va mee boirit nagh veagh Gaelg dy liooar aym's dy loayrt rish lhied yn. . . Cha jagh mee gys y thing. Nish ta mee gra mee hene, 'Ta shen caa caillt, er lhiam' Agh va mee ro faitagh dy jannoo shen. Va enney mie er yn dooinney agh va mee ro faitagh dy goll gys e hie dy jannoo coloayrtys marish yn ard ghooinney eh hene.
English: I was sent to his house to talk to him but I was too shy. I was worried that I wouldn't know enough Manx to speak to the like... I didn't go to the thing. Now I say to myself, 'That's a chance lost, I think' But I was too shy to do that. I was well acquainted with the man but I was too shy to go to his house and make conversation with the great man himself.

Manx: Quoi elley va gynsaghey Gaelg tra v'ou gynsaghey ee?
English: Who else was leaning Manx when you were learning it?

Manx: Well, tra va mish aeg, mysh shey jeig bleeantyn dy eash, va dooinney cummal ayns yn Straid Eayl ayns Purt le Moirrey ayns thie enmyssit Valley Veg.
English: Well, when I was young, about sixteen years old, there was a man living in Lime Street in Port St. Mary in a house called Valla Veg.

Manx: Oh yeah. Shione d'ou yn thie shen.
English: Oh yeah. I know that house.

Manx: Va dooinney cummal ayns shoh enmyssit Walter Kodhere v'ad gra Walter Jane Ann- Cha nel, Walter Annie Jane Ann son far ennym rish yn dooinney shen. As va eshyn lhome lane dy Ghaelg, as v'eh dy kinjagh fockley magh padjer y Çhiarn er my hon ayns y Gaelg. As v'eh gynsaghey focklyn d'ou. As va blass feer feer lajer ec yn dooinney shen. Walter. Walter Annie Jane Ann. Er lhiam's dy row Annie Jane Ann e warree as va ish ben insee ec yn scoill Rushen ayns shoh. Annie Watterson, er lhiam's. Shen e warree er lhiam's. Agh va eshyn lhome lane dy Ghaelg. As va daa huyr ec yn dooinney shen. Va fer. . .enmyssit Olive, as shuyr elley, t'eh jarroodit aym yn ennym v'urree nish, agh va Gaelg ec y neesht jeu. V'ad fuirraght faggys da'n thie oast yn Baie ayns shen, er Primrose Terrace ayns shen. Va Gaelg dy liooar ec y neesht jeu. As va my ayr goll gys yn thie dy jannoo beggan dy daah ayns yn thie, as va my ayr çheet dy valley as v'eh gra rhym's ram focklyn ass y Gaelg ren eh gynsaghey ayns yn thie tra v'ad loayrt.
English: There was a man living there called Walter Watterson who they called Walter Jane Ann- no, Walter Annie Jane Ann as a nickname. And he was full of Manx, and he would always recite the Lord's prayer for me in Manx. And he taught me words. And his accent was very very strong. Walter. Walter Annie Jane Ann. I think Annie Jane Ann was his grandmother, who was a teacher at Rushen school here. Annie Watterson, I think. That was his grandmother, I think. But he was full of Manx. And he had two sisters. There was one...called Olive, and another sister, I've forgotten what her name was now, but they both knew Manx. They lived near to the Bay pub there, on Primrose Terrace there. They both spoke plenty of Manx. And my father went to the house to do a bit of painting in the house, and my father came home and told me lots of words in Manx that he had learned in the house when they were talking.

Manx: As ren oo goll dys brastyllyn marish Doolish y Karagher?
English: And did you go to classes with Douglas Faragher?

Manx: Hie mee gys yn brastyl Ritchie son daa vleeaney, er lhiam's, ayns Balley Cashtal. Va shen yn kied vrastyl va mee ayn. Eisht hie mee gys yn brastyl Doolish y Karagher ayns Doolish son un vlein, er lhiam's. Va Derek Phillips ayn ayns y vrastyl cheddin ec y traa t'ayn, as kuse dy leih elley, Stewie Bennett as sleih myr shen. V'eh feer ymmydoil goll gys y vrastyl.
English: I went to Ritchie's class for two years, I think, in Castletown. That was the first class I was in. Then I went to Douglas Faragher's class for a year, I think. Derek Phillips was in the same class at that time, and a few other people. Stewie Bennett and people like that. It was very useful going to the class.

Manx: Cha bee shiu geddyn greim er y choloayrtys mannagh vel shiu goll gys yn- t'ou slane caillt my row shiu lhaih eh, lhig dooin gra, yn Bible Casherick. T'eh feer doillee geddyn yn aght dy ockley magh eh, my t'ou laccal. Cha nel eh jannoo eh.
English: You won't get a hang of conversation if you don't go to- you're completely lost if you read, let's say, the Holy Bible. It's very difficult to get how to pronounce it, if you like. It doesn't do it.

Manx: As ta ram Gallic ayd nish.
English: And you know a lot of Gallic now.

Manx: Well tha facal na dha agam.
English: Well, 'I know a word or two'

Manx: So t'ou goll gys Ellan Barra feer vennick. Vel oo goll er yn vaatey ayd?
English: So you go to Barra often. Do you go in your boat?

Manx: Cha nel. Er yn etlan, ghooinney.
English: No. On the plane, man.

Manx: T'eh ro foddey dy gholl er y vaatey. S'cooin lhiam yn kied turrys, mysh jeih bleeaney er dy henney. Va mish loayrt marish carrey dooys, dooinney enmyssit Raghnall Campbell, as va shinyn cheu mooie jeh ny booaghyn, as va thie bee noa goll er karraghey heese yn traid, as haink ven magh ass yn shapp as dooyrt y ven rish my charrey, 'Bheil e fosgailte fhathast?' As va mee smooinaghtyn d'ou hene, dooyrt y ven, 'Vel eh foshlit foast? Is it open yet?'
English: It's too far to go in the boat. I remember the first trip, about ten years ago. I was talking to a friend of mine, a man called Ronald Campbell, and we were outside of the cows, and there was a new restaurant being renovated down the road, and a woman came out of the shop and the woman said to my friend, 'Bheil e fosgailte fhathast?' And I thought to myself, the woman said, 'Is it open yet?'

Manx: As dooyrt mee, 'Ta mee toiggal yn glare shoh, gyn ourys' 'Bheil e fosgailte fhathast?' dooyrt ish. As dooyrt mee rish my charrey, 'Dooyrt ish "is it open yet?" ?' 'Tha thu ceart. Tha thu ag ionnsachadh. You're learning' T'ee yn un red. T'ad gra thàinig - haink. Chì mi thu. As ooilley ny earrooyn, ooilley ny verbyn, dagh ooilley red, t'ad ooilley yn un red, agh t'ad fockley magh eh ayns aght beggan quaagh. My row shiu geddyn cliaghtit rish t'eh aashagh dy liooar dy toiggal eh.
English: And I said, 'I understand this language, without doubt' 'Is it open yet?' she said. And I said to my friend, 'Did she say "is it open yet?"?' 'You're right. You're learning.' It's the same thing. They say thàinig – 'haink' [came]. Chì mi thu [see you]. And all the numbers, all the verbs, everything, they're all the same, but they pronounce it in a bit of a strange way. If you get used to it it's easy enough to understand it.

Manx: Agh t'adsyn loayrt Gallic feiy'n laa gagh laa. Agh v'adsyn gra dy vel eh goll sheese y lhargagh ec y traa t'ayn, as dooyrt shenn fer insee ta cummal ayns Barra, dooyrt eshyn rhym's, 'Ta dooinney loayrt Baarle ayns gagh chorneil jeh gagh thie gagh oie' V'eh loayrt mychione yn chelveish. As dooyrt eh, va shenn sleih goit er y Vaarle er yn oyr dy vel ad smooinnaghtyn dy vel eh cool dy ve loayrt ass y Vaarle. Cha nel eh cool dy ve loayrt ass y Ghallic. Shen myr dooyrt yn dooinney shen.
English: But they speak Gallic all day every day. But they said that it's going downhill at the moment, and an old teacher who lives in Barra, he said to me, 'There's a man speaking English in every corner of every home every night.' He was talking about the television. And he said old people were taken by English because they thought it was cool to be speaking in English. It's not cool to be speaking Gallic. That's what this man said.

Manx: S'bastagh shen. Vel oo son goll dys Barra mleeaney?
English: That's a shame. Are you going to Barra this year?

Manx: Aye, ayns mee ny ghaa. Ta mee er ve ayn jeih turrys, er lhiam's.
English: Aye, in a month or two. I've been on ten trips, I think.

Manx: C'raad t'ou tannaghtyn?
English: Where do you stay?

Manx: Well, boayl erbee. Ta mee geddyn bwaane mar is trice. Mar is trice, ta shen Gallic, ghooinney. Mar is trice - 'most often'.
English: Well, anywhere. I get a cottage mar is trice. Mar is trice, that's Gallic, man. Mar is trice – 'most often'.

Manx: Ny s'menkey.
English: More often.

Manx: Ta mee geddyn caillt, ny keayrtyn, eddyr y ghlare Vanninagh as y Ghallic.
English: I get lost, sometimes, between the Manx language and Gallic.

Manx: Foddym toiggal shen. T'eh beggan doillee, nagh vel? Feer vie. Cre nee oo 'sy tourey ansherbee? Vel oo son jannoo veg? Well, goll dys Barra.
English: I can understand that. It's a bit difficult, isn't it? Very good. What are you doing in the summer anyway? Are you doing anything? Well, going to Barra.

Manx: Aye, as goll gys y Rank dy chur shilley er my inneen. T'ee ayns yn ard scoill ayns shen. T'ee jannoo studeyrys er Frangish, as delladys. Delladys, t'ad gra rish.
English: Aye, and going to France to visit my daughter. She's at university there. She's studying French and business, I think. Business, they call it.

Manx: C'raad sy Rank?
English: Where in France?

Manx: Leon, er lhiam's t'ee ayn. Eisht sy fouyr er lhiam's dy vel ee goll gys Bordeaux son jannoo startey son blein, agh lurg shen t'ee jannoo yn blein sy jerrey ec ard scoill ayns Chester, eisht foddee dy bee degree ecksh.
English: Leon, I think she's in. Then in the autumn I think that she's going to Bordeaux to work for a year, but after that she's doing the final year at university in Chester, then maybe she'll have a degree.

Manx: As c'red t'ee geearree- laccal jannoo lurg shen?
English: And what does she want to do after that?

Manx: Cha nel ish smooinaghtyn mychione y lhied shen. T'ee just smooinaghtyn mychione goll magh er yn oie ec y traa t'ayn.
English: She's not thinking about that type of thing. She's just thinking about going out at night at the moment.

Manx: Cre'n fa nagh.
English: Why not.

Manx: T'ee jannoo delladys as t'ee jannoo Frangish. Ta mish er gra, 'Bee startey mie ayd's ayns Ellan Vannin' 'Oh, cha nel. Beeym goll ooilley mygeayrt y theihll' dooyrt ee. Hee shin.
English: She's doing business and she's doing French. I've said, 'There'll be a good job on the Isle of Man' 'Oh, no. I'll be going all round the world' she said. We will see.

Manx: As cre mychione dty vac? Vel eh gobbraghey mayrt er y vaatey?
English: And what about your son? Is he working with you on the boat?

Manx: Er y vaatey. T'eh er ve er y vaatey three bleeaney nish. T'eh jannoo dy mie. Dooinney lajer. Dooinney braew t'eh. As tra ta mish my haaue s'treisht lhiam bee eshyn goll magh ayns y vaatey eh hene. S'treisht lhiam.
